item.title: Prosus expects 5 IPOs from its India portfolio in next 18 months
item.dc:creator: Manish Singh
item.description:
Prosus anticipates as many as five potential IPOs from its Indian portfolio over the next 18 months, signalling growing momentum in the world’s second-largest internet market. The Dutch investment group on Monday named payments giant PayU, e-commerce startup Meesho, and online jewelry seller Bluestone among the startups that are preparing for an IPO. item.title: ‘Brain rot’ wins as Oxford’s word of the year
item.dc:creator: Connie Loizos
item.description:
According to Oxford University Press, which publishes the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the term ‘brain rot’ is defined as the “supposed deterioration of a person’s mental or intellectual state” as it relates to overdosing on online content without much of a narrative — like TikTok videos. Brain rot is also the outfit’s so-called word of […]

item.title: Swiggy scales 10-minute food delivery to 400 cities in quick-commerce push
item.dc:creator: Manish Singh
item.description:
Swiggy has expanded its 10-minute food delivery service to more than 400 cities and towns across India.

item.title: AWS opens physical outlets that let customers upload their data
item.dc:creator: Kyle Wiggers
item.description:
At its re:Invent 2024 conference in Las Vegas, Amazon on Sunday announced a somewhat unusual new service for Amazon Web Services (AWS) customers: Data Transfer Terminal, a set of physical locations where customers can plug in their storage devices to upload data to the AWS cloud. So how’s it work, exactly? From the AWS management […]

item.title: AWS launches an incident response service to combat cybersecurity threats
item.dc:creator: Kyle Wiggers
item.description:
Companies often struggle with how to respond to cybersecurity incidents. According to one recent poll, only three out of five organizations have an incident response plan in place, and only around a third do regular drills to ensure that their plans remain effective. The consequences of poor incident response are costly. The International Monetary Fund […]

item.title: AWS wants to make your call center interactions less painful
item.dc:creator: Frederic Lardinois
item.description:
Slowly but surely, Amazon’s AWS cloud computing unit has become a major player in the call/contact center space with its Amazon Connect cloud-based (and AI-centric) contact center service, which launched back in 2017. Today, companies like Air Canada, Dish Network and U.S. Bank use the platform for their customer service needs. At its annual re:Invent […]

item.title: Y Combinator’s Demo Day is back in person
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description:
As promised, startup accelerator Y Combinator’s imminent Demo Day will be happening in person. In fact, YC seems to have kicked off the IRL return of Demo Day at the end of the long Thanksgiving weekend, with an in-person Alumni Demo Day on Sunday for the Fall 2024 class of startups.  Squad founder (and later […]

item.title: Death Clock app predicts the date of your death
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description:
A new app called Death Clock predicts the date of its users’ deaths and offers tips on how to push that date back. TechCrunch wrote about an iPod Death Clock app way back in 2006 — but developer Brett Franson told Bloomberg that with an AI trained on more than 1,200 life expectancy studies, his […]

item.title: Fidelity reportedly marked up its X stake by 32 percent
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description:
Fidelity marked up the value of its holdings in Elon Musk’s X (formerly Twitter) by 32.37% in October, according to a report in Axios. Even with this markup, Fidelity still values the company at 72 percent less than the $44 billion that Musk purchased it for in 2022. Axios reports that this move is probably […]

item.title: Best Apple Watch apps for boosting your productivity
item.dc:creator: Aisha Malik
item.description:
The Apple Watch helps people track their health and fitness, but it can also be a great tool to help people stay productive and get work done. This is especially true for people who gets easily distracted by their phone. Although the Apple Watch comes with simple built-in productivity apps like Reminders and Calendar, it’s […]

item.title: Bluesky promises more verification and an ‘aggressive’ approach to impersonation
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description:
As more celebrities and popular influencers join Bluesky, the fast-growing social media service has been facing more concerns around impersonation and verified identity. The Bluesky Safety team posted Friday that the company has updated its impersonation policy to be “more aggressive,” adding that “impersonation and handle-squatting accounts will be removed.” The company said it should […]

item.title: Elon Musk files for injunction to halt OpenAI’s transition to a for-profit
item.dc:creator: Kyle Wiggers
item.description:
Attorneys for tech billionaire Elon Musk have filed for a preliminary injunction against OpenAI, several of its co-founders, and its investor and close collaborator, Microsoft, to prevent OpenAI and other named defendants from engaging in what Musk’s counsel claims is anticompetitive behavior. The motion for an injunction, which was filed late on Friday in the […]

item.title: Why Olympic champion cyclist Sir Chris Hoy is backing Skarper to make any bike an e-bike
item.dc:creator: Paul Sawers
item.description:
As one of the most decorated track cyclists of all time, Sir Chris Hoy might not seem an obvious candidate to back the burgeoning electric bike movement. The common refrain, after all, is that e-bikes aren’t real bikes. However, the six-time Olympic gold medalist has done exactly that, investing in a fledgling U.K. startup that […]

item.title: Climate VCs are cautiously optimistic about a second Trump term — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Tim De Chant, Rebecca Szkutak
item.description:
President-elect Donald Trump made no secret during his campaigning that he doesn’t think the U.S. should take an aggressive stance on climate change. From leading chants of “drill, baby, drill” to frequently criticizing everything from wind turbines to electric vehicles, he appears poised to cast a shadow over the climate tech sector for the next […]

item.title: Black Friday hits a record $74.4B in sales online, up 5% on last year
item.dc:creator: Ingrid Lunden
item.description:
The momentum of Thanksgiving — which saw consumers spend a record $33.6 billion spent globally online on the day — looks like it continued into Black Friday, with a bang. Adobe said that in the U.S., consumers made a record-breaking $10.8 billion of purchases, up 10.2% on last year. Meanwhile, Salesforce is giving a much […]

item.title: Joco almost died at launch. Now, it’s a lifeline for e-bike delivery riders — and a profitable business
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description:
On a September morning in 2024, two Jonathan Cohens — one from the Rockaways in Queens, the other from London — stood in an empty 15,000-square-foot parking garage near Hudson Yards in New York City. As they walked over chipped yellow lines, they explained how the space would help Joco, their shared e-bike startup for […]

item.title: Canadian news companies sue OpenAI
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description:
A group of Canadian news and media companies filed a lawsuit Friday against OpenAI, alleging that the ChatGPT maker has infringed their copyrights and unjustly enriched itself at their expense. The companies behind the lawsuit include the Toronto Star, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the Globe and Mail, and others who seek to win monetary damages […]

item.title: Study of ChatGPT citations makes dismal reading for publishers
item.dc:creator: Natasha Lomas
item.description:
As more publishers cut content licensing deals with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI, a study put out this week by the Tow Center for Digital Journalism — looking at how the AI chatbot produces citations (i.e. sources) for publishers’ content — makes for interesting, or, well, concerning, reading. In a nutshell, the findings suggest publishers remain at the […]

item.title: ASL Aspire wants to gamify STEM education for deaf kids
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description:
Poor literacy skills have plagued the deaf and hard of hearing community for decades. The median literacy rates of deaf high school graduates have languished at a fourth-grade level since the turn of the 20th century, according to the National Center for Special Education Research.
